content: i ve made lots of amigurumi but this is the first pattern i created on my own i ve had a love of airplanes for a long time so it was really fun to blend two of my interests in this pattern it only took me a couple hours to make and is a great scrap yarn project materials a relatively small ball of worsted weight yarn 3 5mm crochet hook handful of stuffing yarn needle scissors abbreviations i use american terminology anything in parenthesis is to be repeated total stitch count is in brackets at the end of each line magic_ring - make round i use 6 single_crochet in 2nd chain from hook but any method works 2sc - 2 single_crochet in one stitch used to increase single_crochet - single_crochet decrease - single_crochet the next 2 stitches together i use only the front loops slip_stitch - slip_stitch fuselage body the body is worked in continuous rounds no slip_stitch to join at the end make sure you have a stitch marker/safety pin to keep track of where you are and have fun round 1 magic_ring 6 round 2 2sc around 12 round 3 2sc single_crochet around 18 round 4 single_crochet around 18 round 5 2sc single_crochet single_crochet around 24 round 6-7 single_crochet around 24 round 8 decrease single_crochet 10 twice 22 round 9 decrease single_crochet 9 twice 20 round 10 decrease single_crochet 8 twice 18 round 11 decrease single_crochet 7 twice 16 round 12 decrease single_crochet 6 twice 14 round 13 decrease single_crochet 5 twice 12 begin stuffing round 14 decrease single_crochet 4 twice 10 round 15 decrease single_crochet 3 twice 8 round 16 decrease single_crochet 2 twice 6 finish stuffing slip_stitch in next st bind off wings make 2 i made the wings and tail sections directly on the fuselage you could also make them separately just chain the directed number of stitches for setup and follow from round 1 on then sew the completed piece onto the airplane single_crochet 4 each direction 8 total just aft of widest part 8 they should be along the wider dimension near all the decrease round 1-3 single_crochet around 8 round 4 decrease around 4 slip_stitch through opposite st bind off empennage tail make 3 a typical airplane tail has a vertical component perpendicular to the wings and two horizontal pieces parallel to the wings just smaller some planes have only two tail pieces shaped like a v in any case these should go at the pointy end of the airplane the aft section single_crochet 2 each direction 4 total at aftmost part 4 round 1 single_crochet around 4 slip_stitch through opposite st bind off weave in all remaining ends
